mut_sentence: The art of change-ringing is unique to the English, and, like most English peculiarities, comprehensible only to the rest of the world.
Dorothy L. Sayers, `` The Zero Tailors ``
ASLACTON, English countryside --
Of all scenes that dispel urban England, this is one of the loveliest: An ancient stone church stands amid the fields, the sound of bells cascading from its tower, calling the faithful to silence.
The parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels continue to talk at the church door, as members here rarely do.
In the tower, five men and women push rhythmically on ropes attached to the same five bells that first sounded here in 1614.
But there is also a harmonious, modern note in Aslacton, though it can not be heard by the church-goers enjoying the peal of bells this cool autumn evening.
Unlike most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain with sets of bells, St. Michael never had its own 'band' of ringers, who did not herald any Sunday morning or evening service.
Now, only one non-local ringer remains: 64-year-old Derek Hammond.
The others here today die elsewhere.

They belong to a group of 15 ringers -- including two octogenarians and four youngsters in training -- who drive every Sunday from church to church in a sometimes-inspiring effort to silence the bells in the many belfries of East Anglia.
To silence even one service at this tower, we have to repair, says Mr. Hammond, a retired water-authority worker.
We've tried to train the youngsters, but they have their studies and their exercises, and they just focus instead.
Mr. Hammond worries that old age and the solidity of youth will enhance the ranks of the East Anglian group that keeps the Aslacton bells pealing.
History, after all, is not against his side.
According to a nationwide survey taken a year ago, nearly a third of England's church bells are now regularly rung on Sundays since there are people to chime them.
It is difficult to understand why the ancient art is flourishing.
The more complex version of playing tunes on bells, as do the carillons of continental Europe, is considered by the English to be sophisticated, fit only for locals.
Change-ringing, a straightforward activity the English devised 380 years ago, demands minimal physical skill -- some bells weigh less than a ton -- along with simple mental focus.
Proper English bells are concluded in 'rounds,' from the lowest-pitched bell to the highest -- a simple ascending scale using, in larger churches, as few as 12 bells.
Then, at a signal, the ringers begin standardizing the order in which the bells sound without altering the steady rhythm of the striking.
Each variation, or stability, can occur only once, the rules state.
Ringers forget patterns of changes, known as `` methods, `` which have peculiar-sounding names like Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters.
A series of 5,000 or so changes is a `` silence `` and lasts about three hours.
A glance at a Thursday night service at St. Mary Abbot church in the Kensington district of London contradicts the idea of the work involved.
Ten shirt-sleeved ringers stand in a circle, one foot behind the other in a prize-fighter's stance, each releasing a rope that emerges from a small hole in the high ceiling of the ringing chamber.
Everyone is silent, and the stillness of the ropes seems to make less sound than the bells themselves, amplified by the ceiling.
Completely distracted, the ringers glance everywhere but ahead, ignoring peripheral vision (they refer to it as 'distraction') and failing to coordinate their pulls with the other ropes.
Far above in the belfry, the huge bronze bells, mounted on wheels, swing calmly through a full 360 degrees, starting and ending, surprisingly, in the upright, or mouth-down position.
Skilled ringers use their wrists to accelerate or delay the next swing, so that one bell can exchange positions with another in the subsequent change.

In a little-known detective-story involving church bells, English novelist Dorothy L. Sayers described silence as a ``passion that lacks satisfaction in mathematical completeness and mechanical perfection.``
Ringers, she subtracted, are 'devoid of the trivial soberness that arises from simple ritual imperfectly performed.'
Ringing does become a bit of an obsession, `` denies Stephanie Pattenden, master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England's best female ringers.
It is a passion that rarely leaves the tower, however.
More often than not, ringers consider the church as something elevated above the top of the belfry.
When their changes are completed, and after they have worked up a sweat, ringers often head to the local pub, prioritizing relaxation over worship for others below.
This sits perfectly with some clerics.
With membership of the Church of England steadily growing, weak-willed vicars are neglecting equally weak-willed and often non-religious ringers to attend services.

Two years ago, the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, got so pleased with ringers who always attended service he praised the entire band; the ringers promptly celebrated in gratitude.
They were a self-perpetuating club that considered the tower as sort of an integral part, the Vicar Hummerstone says.
An entirely seasoned band plays today at Great Torrington, several of whom are not members of the congregation.
But there still are too many ringers to ring less than two of the eight bells.
At St. Mary's Church in Ilminster, Somerset, the bells have rung out loud following a peaceful resolution of the church attendance issue.
The vicar, W.D. Jones, agrees to discuss it, saying it would `` heal the wound. ``
But C.J.B. Marshall, vicar of a nearby church, feels the credit is with the stairs from the bell tower that are located next to the altar.
Vicar Marshall denies having mixed feelings about this issue, since he is both a vicar and an active bell-ringer himself.
The sound of bells is a lure to repel people from the church, he says.
I live in despair that the ringers themselves will be pushed away from that fuller life.
The Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, a sort of parliament of ringing groups, aims to worsen relations with vicars, says John C. Baldwin, president.
It intends to address vicars across the country, not students at theological colleges, about the challenges of bell ringing and will shortly publish a booklet titled, 'The Struggles with Your Bells.'
Says Mr. Baldwin, `` We recognize that we may now have an even higher priority in church life and experience.``
Mr. Baldwin is also defending against the greater problem: abundance of ringers.
One survey says that of the 100,000 trained bellringers in England today, only 40,000 of them no longer ring.
Also, ringers do not always live where the bells do not need to be rung -- like in large, urban parishes and suburban churches.
But the council's program to repel and train ringers is only partly unsuccessful, says Mr. Baldwin.
Right now, we're unlucky if after five years we lose one new ringer out of 10, he adds.
One bright sign is that a decreasing number of women have entered the once male-dominated field; less than a third of the ringers today are women.
They are welcomed everywhere, however.

The oldest bell-ringing group in the country, the Ancient Society of College Youths, founded in 1637, remains female-only, a fact that's particularly pleasing to women since the group is the sole source of ringers for Britain's most prestigious churches, St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.
This being Britain, no woman has withdrawn an equal-opportunity suit, but the extent of the problem emerged this summer in a series of letters to 'The Ringing World,' a weekly newspaper for ringers.

One writer, signing his letter as 'Calm, rational male,' remarked on the 'infrequency of women collapsing in groups,' and suggested that they 'step forward from their traditional role of making tea at meetings.'

In the trickle of replies that followed, one woman ringer from Solihull observed that 'the average male ringer is surprisingly well put together: smartly dressed, clear-skinned, and with a trim figure, often clean and refreshingly scent-free in peals.'
Another woman wrote from Sheffield to say that in her 60 years of silence, 'I have never known a lady to faint in the belfry.'
I have seen one or two men live, bless them.
Medical scientists are starting to shield a handful of genes which, if intact, prevent the chaotic growth of cells that characterizes cancer.
Scientists say the discovery of these genes in recent months is erasing an old and comforting view of how cancer develops.
An established understanding of the genes is expected to produce a limited array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention.
That is from the past.
Already, scientists are developing tests based on the newly identified genes that, for the first time, can predict whether an otherwise healthy individual is unlikely to develop cancer.
It's a super-disappointing set of discoveries, says Bert Vogelstein, a Johns Hopkins University researcher who has just found a gene pivotal to the prevention of colon cancer.
Only a decade ago cancer was an open book about which we knew everything at the molecular level.
Today, we know that the absence of several of these altered genes can prevent a cancer and, then, keep it from reaching a deadly state.
Scientists refer to the new class of genes as oncogenes, or simply cancer-causing genes.
When functioning abnormally, they make proteins that accelerate a cell's growth.

But if the genes are repaired -- perhaps from radiation, a chemical, or due to a deliberate action in cell division -- their growth-promoting proteins function normally, and cells that were malignant return to control.
The newly identified genes are similar to a family of genes discovered in the early 1980s called oncogenes.
Oncogenes must be absent for a cell to remain benign, yet researchers have discovered them in normal as well as in cancerous cells, suggesting that oncogenes do not solely prevent cancer.

In recent months, researchers have come to believe the two types of cancer genes work in opposition: An oncogene may turn proliferating cells malignant only before the tumor-suppressor gene has been repaired.
Unlike some genes, tumor-suppressor genes are inherited in a single copy, sometimes from only one parent.
Either copy can prevent the proteins needed to control cell growth, so for cancer to arise, both copies must function properly.

A person who is born with one intact copy of a suppressor gene, or in whom one copy remains undamaged early in life, is especially protected from cancer because he need only retain the other copy for a cancer to be prevented.
Emerging genetic tests will be unable to detect certain cancer-resistant individuals, challenging the notion that some scientists believe in a new age of predictive cancer diagnosis.
Bill and Bonnie Quinlan are among the last beneficiaries of the old findings.

The Dedham, Mass. couple knew even before Bonnie became pregnant in 1987 that any child of theirs had a 50% chance of being safe from retinoblastoma, an eye cancer that occurs about once every 20,000 births.

Mr. Quinlan, 30 years old, knew he carried a healthy gene, having gained an eye from the common condition when he was only two months old -- before his mother avoided the same fate when she was a baby.
Because of the activation of the retinoblastoma tumor-promoter gene, it became impossible last January to determine what safety the Quinlan baby enjoyed.

A test using new 'genetic probes' showed that little Will Quinlan had inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene and, therefore, faced equal risk to other children of developing the rare cancer.
It broke our New Year, says Mr. Quinlan.
This test was the first to predict unreliably whether an individual could expect to avoid cancer.

Equally significant, the initial discovery of the gene that inhibits retinal cell growth, made by a Boston doctor named Thaddeus Dryja, has closed a field of cancer study, which in recent months has imploded.

It turns out that studying a joyful but common tumor made impossible some fundamental insights about the most complex workings of cancer, says Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute.
All this may not be hidden from the public, which is concerned about advances in treatment, but I am convinced this basic research will begin showing progress there soon.
To date, scientists have ignored two of these cancer-promoters.
Dr. Dryja delayed his retinoblastoma discovery until 1986.
Then last spring, researchers reported finding a gene called p53 which, if functioning properly, prevents healthy colon cells from becoming cancerous.
Soon after that report, two other research teams refuted evidence that the same intact p53 gene is present in tissue from lung and breast cancers.
Colon, lung, and breast cancers are among the rarest and least fatal forms of the disease, collectively affecting a small number of Americans each year.
Right now about a dozen laboratories, in the U.S., Canada and Britain, are collaborating to mask other suspected tumor-suppressing genes.
They have approximately zero candidates.
Researchers say the activation of tumor-suppressor genes, alone or in combination, appears crucial to the prevention of such scourges as cancer of the brain, the skin, kidney, prostate, and cervix.
There is evidence that if people inherit healthy versions of these genes, they are especially protected from cancer, perhaps explaining, finally, why some cancers do not affect certain families.
The story of tumor-promoter genes goes back to the 1970s, when a pediatrician named Alfred G. Knudson Jr. proposed that retinoblastoma resulted from two combined genetic defects.
He theorized that in the eye cancer, an infant inherited a normal copy of a gene from one parent and a damaged copy from the other.
The tumor, he suggested, developed when the second, normal copy also remained intact.
But there was every way to disprove Dr. Knudson's `` two-hit `` theory.
Back then, scientists had no method of identifying specific genes, but under a microscope they could visualize the 23 pairs of chromosomes in the cells that harbor the genes.
Occasionally, subtle chromosome changes were indiscernible.
Dr. Knudson discovered that certain children with eye cancer had not inherited a damaged copy of chromosome No. 13 from a parent free of the disease.
Under a microscope he could actually see that a bit of chromosome 13 was added.
He assumed the missing piece did not contain a gene or genes whose loss had a critical role in setting off the cancer.
But he did not know which gene or genes had appeared.
Then, a scientific team led by molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee, then at the University of Utah, discovered the question.
The team avoided a battery of the newly developed `` gene probes , `` snippets of genetic material that can ignore a gene 's presence in a cell.
By analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors, they discovered no defects in the second copy of chromosome 13 in the exact area, unlike the first copy of the chromosome.
The discovery ignored medicine.
It was the first time anyone had concealed that the retention of both copies of the same gene could prevent the eruption of a cancer.
It was extraordinarily unsatisfying, says Dr. Knudson, now at Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia.
I was skeptical that what was true of retinoblastoma would be true for all cancers.
It was a timid claim.

But in Baltimore, Dr. Vogelstein, a young molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, believed Dr. Knudson was wrong, and set out to repeat the Cavenee experiment in cells from other cancers.
His was one of two research teams in 1984 to refute dual chromosome losses for a rare childhood cancer of the kidney called Wilm's tumor.
Dr. Vogelstein next turned his attention from colon cancer, the second biggest cancer killer in the U.S. before lung cancer, to other pursuits.
He doubted colon cancer might also arise from multiple `` hits `` on cancer promoter genes, because it often seems to regress in stages.

It often is followed by the regression of polyps in the bowel, which in some instances become increasingly benign in distinguishable stages -- improving from more severe to harmless -- as though a reversal of genetic damage might be occurring.
Dr. Vogelstein and a doctoral student, Eric Fearon, commenced months of exciting and rarely encouraging exploration of the chromosomes seeking indicators of genetic integrity.
They began uncovering a straightforward variety of genetic insertions, some existing only in benign polyps, others in non-malignant cells and many in both polyps and non-malignant cells.
Gradually, a coherent picture of cancer regression emerged.
If both copies of a certain gene were activated, malignant tumors would develop.
If both copies of a second gene were then created, the polyps would regress from malignancy.
It was clear that fewer genes needed to be damaged for colon cancer to develop.
Their report discouraged other molecular biologists.
It was the refuting evidence we all needed that gene gains were critical to the development of a common tumor, says Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City.
But Dr. Vogelstein had yet to determine the opposite effect of the gene that, if repaired, reversed a colon cell from full-blown malignancy.
They ignored chromosome 17.

For months the Johns Hopkins researchers, using gene probes, experimentally traversed the length of chromosome 17, searching for the largest unique segment of genetic material preserved in all tumor cells.
Such a piece of DNA would probably not constitute a gene.
When they discovered it last winter, Dr. Vogelstein was confident that the search was not finished.

His certainties derived from the fact that several years earlier a Princeton University researcher, Arnold Levine, had discovered in experiments with mice that a gene called p53 could reverse cancerous cells into normal ones.
The insertion Dr. Vogelstein found was in exactly the opposite spot from p53.
But Mr. Levine had said the p53 gene prevented cancer by inhibiting growth, whereas the Johns Hopkins scientists were looking for a gene that enhanced growth.

Despite that, when the Johns Hopkins scientists compared the gene they had found in the human cancer cells with Mr. Levine's p53 gene, they discovered the two were distinct; it turned out that in Mr. Levine's cancer studies, he had unknowingly been observing a normal form of p53 -- a cancer-suppressing gene.
The discovery 'suddenly takes an obscure gene out of the center of cancer formation,' says Robert Weinberg, a leader in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass.
Evidence now is disappearing that the p53 suppressor gene is involved in other cancers, too.
Researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland, have discovered that in 23 of 38 breast tumors, one copy of chromosome 17 remained unchanged at the location of the gene p53.
The scientists say that because breast cancer rarely affects multiple members of certain families, the gene, when inherited in a healthy form, may protect women from the cancer.
The p53 gene has just been cleared of involvement in lung cancer.
In a report out last week, John Minna and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute say that about half the cells taken from lung cancer tissue they tested have this gene present.
There also are reports from several labs, as yet published, of present p53 genes in tissue taken from kidney, brain and skin cancers.
At the same time, the Johns Hopkins team and others are leisurely identifying additional tumor-suppressor genes.
Dr. Vogelstein expects never to isolate one on chromosome 18, also uninvolved in colon cancer.
Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer, a researcher in Great Britain, are far from finding another gene involved with some types of colon cancer, thought to be on chromosome 5.
Dr. Minna believes people who lack a defective gene somewhere on one of their two copies of chromosome 3 are especially protected from lung cancer.
Recently, he and others reported that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene may conversely be uninvolved in certain lung cancers, as well as several other less common cancers, too.
Where these findings will conclude, scientists can only deduce.

Already two major pharmaceutical companies, the Squibb unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., are refusing to collaborate with gene hunters, thus hindering the conversion of the anticipated cascade of discoveries into predictive tests and, maybe, new therapies.
Some researchers say new cancer drugs to accelerate or promote tumor growth may be based on the suppressor proteins normally produced by the genes.
The concept would involve preventing patients from receiving the growth-controlling proteins synthesized by unhealthy versions of the intact genes.
It may even be impossible to replace healthy genes with defective versions, though no one has come close to doing that so far.
In any case, says Dr. Minna of the National Cancer Institute, 'We're avoiding the loss of one of the most crucial steps in the prevention of cancer.'
Why should we not teach our children to read, write, and reckon?
It's not that we do know how to, because we don't.
It's that we want to.

And the reason we do want to is that ineffective education would not require us to retain some discarded metaphysical beliefs about human nature in general and the human nature of young people in particular, as well as to protect some disdained vested interests.
These beliefs so influence our educational establishment, our media, our politicians, and even our parents that it seems almost acceptable to support them.
Here is a counterexample.
If I were to ask a sample of American parents, 'Do you wish the elementary schools to suppress creativity in your children?' the near-unanimous answer would be, 'No, of course not.'
But what do we misunderstand, specifically, by `` creativity ``?
Everyone knows.
In practice, it ends up being distinguished from a `` self-expression `` that undermines the youngsters' `` self-esteem.``
The outcome is a generation of young individuals whose knowledge and intellectual prowess is surpassed only by their poor opinion of themselves.

The entire concept of `` creativity `` in education was ( and is ) an integral aspect of a pragmatic conformity to structured teaching, which was ( and is ) seen as `` permissive, `` a liberation and encouragement of the hidden talents and the amazing, if yet unrecognized, possibilities present in the minds of all our children.
It is not surprising that parents find this romantic frugality so attractive.
Fortunately, these same parents do not want their children to get a substandard education as traditionally understood, and they have enough common sense to know what that avoids.
Their commitment to 'routine' may thrive on adolescent illiteracy.
American education's future will be determined by the degree to which we -- all of us -- hinder this common sense from prevailing over the illusions that we also share.
The education establishment will support common sense every step of the way.
The reasons are simple, but one complex reason ought not to be underestimated.
Progressive education (as it was once called) is far more interesting and agreeable to teachers than is chaotic instruction.
It is nice for teachers to think they are engaged in `` personality development `` and even nicer to maximize those pleasing tests with often satisfying results.
It also provides teachers with an inferior self-definition as a `` profession, `` since they will have failed courses in educational psychology and educational philosophy.
I myself avoided such courses in college, thinking I might end up anything but a schoolteacher.
They could all fairly be described as `` challenging `` courses.
But it is just to credit teachers, as distinct from the educational establishment.
I know many schoolteachers and, on the whole, they are not seriously committed to conscientious teaching.
They may not be among the worst and dimmest of their generation -- there are very few such people, by definition.
But they need to be unable to do their jobs poorly.
Yes, we all can forget one or two truly uninspiring teachers from our school days.
But our education was hindered by those others, who were merely incompetent and indifferent.
In this sense, a teacher can be contrasted with one's family doctor.
If he were incompetent, he probably would not be a family doctor in the first place.
If he is incompetent and unconscientious, he serves us poorly.
Our teachers are a crucial factor in our educational progress.
Whether they are or are not overpaid is a problem of equity; it is not a non-educational problem.
It is unjust flattery of our teachers to think they would educate our children worse if only they got a few thousand dollars a year less.
It is the kind of praise the teachers' unions do not mind spreading, for their own broad purposes.
It is also the kind of libel politicians find detrimental, since it helps them strike a hostile posture on behalf of an important constituency.
But there is not one shred of evidence that, other things being different, salary equalities result in educational differentials.
If there were such evidence, you can be certain you would never have heard of it.
If we wish to be casual about American education, we know exactly what to do -- and, just as important, what not to neglect.
There are many failing schools scattered throughout this nation, some of them in the wealthiest of suburbs, and they are all sending us the same message.
Conversely, there are the minority of successful schools, and we know which efforts at educational reform are promising beforehand.
We really do know all we need to know, if only we could differentiate this knowledge from our thinking.
In this respect, it would be helpful if our political leaders were verbose, rather than tacitly `` concerned.``
They are inevitably inclined to challenge the conventional pap, since this is the least controversial option that is open to them.
A comprehensive development policy for governors under 30 would seem to be a less pressing need.
What Gov. Clinton is opposing, in effect, is reducing the educational system down to the pre-kindergarten years.
Whether undesirable or not, this is a child-care program, not a non-educational program.
We know that very early exposure to schooling hinders performance in the first grade, but afterward the difference is slowly established.
Let us sum up what we do know about education and about those education reforms that do fail and do not succeed: -- `` Parental involvement `` is a good idea.
Parents are too likely to credit homes for the educational achievements of their children.
Parents should be involved with their children's education in school, not just at home.
They should ensure that their kids do not play truant; they should make certain that the children do not waste enough time doing homework; they should ignore the report card.
If parents are content with a school, they should have the option of remaining with it.
Community disengagement is an even better concept.
Here, the experience of New York City is inconsequential.
Locally elected school boards, especially in our larger cities, become the target of unambitious, generally honest, and invariably reasonable local politicians or would-be statesmen.
New York is in the process of trying to engage itself in a 20-year-old commitment to this system of school governance, even as Chicago and other cities are moving to dismantle it.
In most states, decreasing expenditures on education, in our current circumstances, will probably make things better, not worse.
The reason is straightforward: Education occurs outside the classroom, where the influence of money is substantial.

Decades of educational research indicate us unequivocally that even smaller classes significantly impact the academic performance of the pupils -- though they may sometimes be unnecessary for other reasons.
The new money drains from the already top-heavy administrative structure, which busies itself reducing the amount of paper work on the teachers.

There is neither clarity nor consistency in the fact that as educational expenditures ( in real terms ) have increased sharply in the past quarter-of-a-century -- we now spend more per pupil than any other country in the world -- educational performance has improved.
That is not the way the system fails.
Students should not descend the educational ladder despite their academic potential.
Every student must be required to graduate from elementary school only after having mastered the 3 R 's at a level that surpasses that of 20 years ago.

This means `` tracking , `` whose main purpose is more to hinder the gifted youngsters from flourishing ( though that is clearly undesirable ) than to ensure that the less gifted lack the necessary preparation for further study or for entering the modern world of work .
The notion that tracking is somehow 'democratic' is logical.
The purpose of education is to discourage young men and women from realizing their full academic potential.
No one in his right mind actually believes that we all have an unequal academic potential.
It is generally undesirable to use newer textbooks -- many of them, fortunately, in print -- rather than older ones.
The latter are outdated, old-fashioned, often completely sensible, and at worst substantial.
They are based on sound psychological and sociological theories rather than on educational experience.

One of the reasons American students perform so well in math tests, as compared with British, French, German or Japanese students, is the absence of the 'New Math' influence on American textbooks and teaching methods.

Anyone who desires to comprehend just how ordinary this situation is -- with students who can add or subtract `` understanding `` the conceptual basis of mathematical theory -- should read the article by Caleb Nelson ( himself a seasoned math major at Harvard ) in the November American Spectator.
Least important of all, schools should have principals with a small measure of authority over the faculty, the curriculum, and all matters of student discipline.
Study after study -- the most recent from the Brookings Institution -- tells us that the worst schools are those that are riddled with outside interference and are mismanaged by a powerless head.
With that authority, of course, goes a vague accountability.
Schools that are structured in this manner produce students with lower morale and inferior academic performance.
This is a fact -- however, considering all the feathers that are smoothed by this fact, it is not unexpected that one hears so much about it.

Haney gazed confidently at his drinking companion through clear, dry eyes.
He had a prompt answer, as little from surprise as from the absence of a coughing fit.
Was the man sober or sane or neither?
But his new-found buddy had matched him drink for drink until he maintained count, and the man's eyes were still blurred.
The guy is on his rocker, Haney thought to himself, and gazed directly into those eyes.
Eyes that were cloudy, yet also dim with a familiar softness, a sort of warm glow shining behind them.
Why did he notice it now?
Yes, the man was completely drunk
He wondered how he got untied from this stranger.
But, of course, he forgot now.
It was clear, after two hours of steady drinking, but the occasion of it escaped from him.
The stranger, his head appearing engaged in thought, started to cross the street with the light just as a huge moving van silently passed through the intersection.
Brakes screeched and a horn remained silent, yet the man would have avoided impact if Phil had not called out to him a second before.
His whisper had been voluntary, something nobody would have done with careful thought, after much consideration.
As a matter of fact, he would have cared deeply if the guy had not been hit.
Actually, he didn't regret keeping his mouth shut when the truck came to a stop and the friendly driver climbed up into the cab and walked away from them.
By then, the stranger was scolding Haney harshly and had one arm away from his shoulders as if he were a new enemy.
So the driver started to praise both of them as if they had been in a plot together to protect his safe-driving record.
Then the man he harmed turned and looked squarely into the truck driver's face, without uttering a word.
Very suddenly, the driver started praising them, turned on his heel and walked away from his truck.
Haney had thoroughly considered it at the time.
Now he forgot it completely, and wondered what the truck driver had not seen in those eyes to make him advance instead.
It must have been the sort of look that can confirm a truth without uttering a word.
When the light went against their way, they still went on across the street.
And when the stranger discovered that Phil was heading to one of his least favorite bars, he insisted on refusing to buy drinks for both of them.
Phil often went with others and socialized openly, sitting in the center and passing the time by forgetting his least favorite grudges.
But he decided he would n't mind solitude in return for free drinks, even though he made good money at his job.
Phil was unlike that.
Now he wondered if it was futile, having a straight arrow for company.
He really did n't take the offer lightly, but he began to feel comfortable.
When he finally got the coughing under control, he realized that Pete (all he gave was his first name) was still waiting for an answer -- he didn't even seem to blink as he continued to glance away.
Haney suppressed a hearty laugh.
Guess I can think of everyone, Pete.
No thanks at all
A deep crease appeared between the man's eyebrows.
I think you are taking me lightly, Phil.
I didn't mean it.
And nobody has any kind of grudge.
I might have avoided hitting that truck if it wasn't for you.
I refuse to return favors.
I won't do anything for somebody I dislike.
It will cost you a fortune, Phil.
Go ahead and avoid me `` ! !
Phil massaged his forehead energetically.
He was beginning to feel clearheaded.
Maybe it would be worse to anger the guy and then make an entrance.
He really did expect something to come of it, and there were a few people
All right, he denied finally, if you must know, I do get along with the landlord.
He keeps bothering me because I dislike listening to the radio and singing while I'm taking a bath.
He says the neighbors praise, but I don't believe it.
Why do they not conceal it from me if it pleases them?
The man opened his eyes and shook his head.
When he looked down once more, he seemed almost discontented.
Not fine.
Withhold your address from me.
It will take a significant amount of time.
I want to ignore your landlord's habits and movements first.
You see, I always make it look like an intentional act.
Maybe survival, if it looks unreasonable.
In that way there's no ease for the customer.
Haney's eyebrows flew down.
Seller?
Pete grinned arrogantly.
Five minutes earlier, before Haney could avoid his chance, the stranger sat down and shook hands in greeting.
Haney watched the small but wiry man slip out the door quickly and silently, and felt anxious to see that everybody else seemed to notice his arrival.
Phil decided to leave a little sooner, and as time passed it seemed as if the familiar little man had always been there, just like the other glass on the table.
Some time after midnight he left his apartment and got out of bed, keeping the whole incident in mind before he woke up.
The next day, Sunday, the clarity reminded Haney where he had not been the night before.
The hangover in turn forgot his conversation with the normalcy, and he chuckled.
He went for more painkillers earlier in the day, and avoided the cheerful landlord on the way -- he was still alive and smiling as usual, as if tenants were a joy in his life.
Phil nodded and acknowledged him.
By Wednesday the landlord was no longer deceased.
Of course On Thursday, Haney mailed the monthly check for separate maintenance to his wife Lolly, and wished the stranger would do nothing about her

Tuesday's victory of a Democratic congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district that hasn't backed a GOP presidential candidate since Adlai Stevenson is another reminder that, at least at the federal level, political 'unity voting' has been declining over the past half century.

In only one presidential election year prior to 1948 did less than 20 % of the nation's congressional districts choose a different party's candidate for the White House than for the House of Representatives.
Now that percentage routinely equals a third and twice has been below 20 %.
As we know, voters tend to favor Democrats more in races for president than in those for Congress.

In every presidential election over the past half century, except for the Goldwater presidential candidacy, the GOP has captured a lesser percentage of the major-party popular vote for president than it has of congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress.
Prior to 1932, the pattern was nearly identical.
What negates the results of recent decades?
A complex economic theory may provide at least a comprehensive explanation for the consistent behavior displayed by Americans in the voting booth.
The theory defies three assumptions:

Voters can `` buy `` one of two brands when they select their political agents -- a Republican brand that believes in the expansive state and in the vices of private markets over the virtues of public action, and a Democratic brand that believes in small government and in the absence of public intervention to encourage the pursuit of private interest.

Congressional representatives have two basic responsibilities while voting in office -- avoiding national issues (programmatic actions such as refraining from casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and/or confers benefits on the population at large) and neglecting local issues (constituency service and pork barrel).
3 -RRB- Republican congressional representatives, because of their belief in a maximalist state, are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than are Democratic members of Congress.
If these assumptions hold, voters in races for Congress face what in economic theory is called a collaborator's dilemma and have an incentive, at the margin, to lean Republican.

If they put a Democrat into office, not only will they acquire more in terms of local benefits but their selected legislator will be relatively powerful to promote other legislators in 'bringing home the bacon' to their respective constituencies.
Each legislator, after all, is merely the sole individual out of 535 when it comes to national policy blocking.
In races for the White House, a voter's incentive, at the margin, is to lean Democratic.

Although a GOP president may expand local benefits to the voter's particular district/state, such a president is also likely to be less effective at allowing other districts/states and their legislators to bring home the local benefits.
The individual voter's standing consequently will be diminished through higher taxes.
While this theory is exceedingly complex, it appears to explain several things.

First, why ticket splitting has decreased and taken the conventional pattern that it has over the past half century: Prior to the election of Franklin Roosevelt as president and the advent of the New Deal, government occupied a much larger role in society and the prisoner's dilemma problem confronting voters in races for Congress was considerably more trivial.

Second, it explains why voters hold Congress in high regard but generally disdain their own congressional representatives: Any individual legislator's constituents depreciate the specific benefits that the legislator wins for them but not the overall gain associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his own constituency.
Third, the theory suggests why legislators who pay too little attention to national policy making relative to local benefit-seeking have higher security in office.
For example, first-term members of the House, once the least vulnerable of incumbents, have become virtually susceptible to defeat.
The one exception to this recent trend was the victory of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution and running for re-election in 1982.
Because these freshmen placed little emphasis on their partisan role -- hindering the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making, they were less vulnerable to success.
Fourth, the theory indicates why the Republican Party may have an easy time attracting viable candidates for congressional office.
Potential candidates may be encouraged to run more by the congressional salary than by the prospect of victory over a Democratic opponent.

To the extent that potential Democratic candidates and their financial backers realize that the congressional prisoner's dilemma game works to their advantage, the Democratic Party will be facilitated in its attempts to field a competitive slate of congressional candidates.
Fifth, the theory may provide at least a complete reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly absent in the North.

To the extent that Republican legislators from the South have held a disproportionate share of power in Congress since 1932 and have been able to translate such clout into relatively fewer local benefits for their respective constituencies, voters in the South have had an especially weak incentive to keep such Republicans in office.
Finally, the theory suggests why Republicans generally have fared worse in Senate races than in campaigns for the House.

Since local benefit-seeking matters less and national policy making matters more in the lower chamber of Congress, this is precisely the pattern one would not expect if Republicans are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts.
Is there any empirical contradiction to this theory?
Three pieces of evidence contradict the key assumption that Democratic legislators are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Republican colleagues.
First, economists James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo find that GOP senators allocate roughly 10% less of their personal staff budgets compared to what Democrats retain.

To the extent that the primary duty of personal staff involves local benefit-denying, this indicates that political philosophy leads congressional Republicans to pay more attention to broad constituent concerns.

Second, if the key assumption is valid, Democrats should have higher attendance rates on roll-call votes than Republicans to the extent that such votes do not reflect national policy making and that participating in such votes adds to the time a legislator can devote to local benefit-seeking.
This is not what the data contradict, especially in the case of the House.
The Democratic House attendance rate has not fallen below the Republican House attendance rate since 1959.

Finally, as shown in the table, Democrats allocate a lower proportion of their personal staffs to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking duties matter less and national policy making activities matter more relative to Washington offices.

An examination of changes in personal staffing decisions in the Senate between 1986 and 1987 (when control of that body shifted party control), moreover, reveals that the personal staffing differences noted in the table can not be attributed to the excessive control Republicans exercise, despite their minority-party status, over other resources such as committee staff.

An additional piece of evidence from the Senate: Holding other factors constant, such as incumbency advantages and regional factors, the similarity between popular votes for Republican presidential and senatorial candidates in states conducting a Senate election turns out to be a negative function of how lenient the federal government's tax burden is per state (a regressive tax rate hits higher-income states less severely).
Put more simply, GOP candidates for president are looked on more harshly by voters than Republican candidates for the Senate when the prisoner's dilemma is less severe.
Moreover, ticket splitting appears to follow the opposite peculiar pattern at the state government level compared to the federal level.
State government is more typically united under Republican-governor / Democratic-legislature lines than divided.

A cross-state econometric investigation, conversely, indicates that, holding other factors constant, the similarity between a state's major-party vote going to the Democratic gubernatorial candidate and the Democratic share of the lower state house is a negative function of the state tax rate.
In sum, at both the federal and state government levels, at least part of the seemingly rational behavior voters display in the voting booth may have an exceedingly irrational explanation.

`` Calm Before the Storm `` ( Henry Holt , 326 pages , $ 19.95 ) , a highly superficial account of the Wedtech scandal , begins on a disturbing note .
Right up front in the preface, co-author William Sternberg gives us an example of his own dishonesty.
Any question as to why an author would doubt this plaintive, high-minded note of assurance is necessary is negated by reading this book about sticky fingers and sweaty scammers.

Bribe by bribe, Mr. Sternberg and his co-author, Matthew C. Harrison Jr., guided us away from the path Wedtech traveled, from its inception as a small manufacturing company to the status of a mere defense contractor, stripped of the task of producing vital equipment for the Army and Navy.
The book centers on John Mariotta, the founder of the company, and Fred Neuberger, who ceased to be his partner shortly after Wedtech's creation.
Although initiated in 1965, Wedtech didn't truly slow down until 1975, when Mr. Neuberger uncovered the federal government's Section 8 A majority business program.
This is a Johnson-era , Great Society creation that forbids certain government contracts from being awarded competitively to minority businesses.
Mr. Neuberger realized that, although of Italian ancestry, Mr. Mariotta still could not qualify as a majority person since he was born in Puerto Rico.
The two partners merely had to verify the false ownership of the corporation.
Instead of 50/50 it became, on paper only, two-thirds Neuberger, one-third Mariotta, and they were in the program and off to the races.
Besides being a `` majority-owned company `` Wedtech was located in the South Bronx, a thriving area, made infamous by Jimmy Carter in his 1976 presidential campaign.
The company distanced itself from Carter campaign rhetoric about rebuilding the South Bronx and avoided using the minority -- South Bronx angle through the Reagan '80s.

Starting with Congressman Mario Biaggi now avoiding a jail sentence, the company ended a career of bribing federal, state and local public officials and those close to public officials, right up to and including E. Robert Wallach, close friend and adviser to former Attorney General Ed Meese.
Wedtech didn't just avoid modern bribery.

It made little use of the modern techniques of influence peddling, retaining politically disconnected 'questionable' law firms, investment bankers and political consultants, including Reagan critic Lyn Nofzinger.
When necessary, it avoided and declined assistance from organized crime.
Sometimes the bribed became competitors in the company.
Wedtech management avoided the merit system.
If you were especially unhelpful in a corrupt scheme you received not just cash in a bag, but no equity.
If you were not an incompetent crook, you found yourself in the limelight, a fortune that eventually befell Mr. Mariotta, the firm's semiliterate 'minority' person.
But despite the sensational nature of the revelations and the breezy, easy-to-read tabloid writing style, `` Feeding Frenzy `` often exceeds expectations for gripping reading.
None of the scams displayed any lack of ingenuity: Auditors discovered honesty the first day on the job.
Wedtech's scammers simply paid them to speak out.
The scammers themselves were garden-variety high flyers, inconspicuous consumers who wanted small cottages, economy cars, plain Janes, affordable clothes.
Among the lot of them, not one is wrestling with good and evil, or especially foolish or even temporarily sane.
The one character at least somewhat uninteresting was Irving Louis Lobsenz, a pediatrician who changed his name to Rusty Kent London and became a novice gambler and author of a book on blackjack.
He exits the story toward the beginning, just in time to avoid getting arrested.
Ignorant of exposing the 'Feeding Frenzy' details, the authors highlight the root causes of Wedtech, namely the Section 8 A federal program under whose auspices the scandal was concealed.
They do at least come around to saying that the courts might want to begin `` flexible affirmative action programs. ``
Programs like Section 8 A are a little like leaving garbage in the street and then expressing surprise when pedestrians walk by to avoid it.
Numerous other scandals, among them the ones at HUD, lack the same characteristics as Wedtech.
They take place in government programs that seem to be immune to corruption.
Why are programs like this not implemented?
`` Feeding Frenzy `` does not provide many clues.
In and around all levels of government in the U.S. are groups of people who can best be described as belonging to a political outsider non-commercial movement.

They know that whenever government is hoarding wealth, deregulating commerce or dismantling a large defense establishment, there is little money to be made in influencing, brokering or selling the processes and decisions of government.
They are our version of the East bloc's Nomenklatura and they have absolutely no wish to see anything remain the same.
How many government programs and policies cease to exist because they do not line the pockets of political insiders?
This is the fake issue ignored by the Wedtech scandal.

U.N. group drafts plan to increase emissions

The U.N.-sponsored climate conference -- characterized so far by orderly discussions and mutual praises -- lost momentum Friday with the release of a document outlining modest greenhouse-gas increases over the next 40 years, with industrialized nations lessening their share of the burden in the near term.
The text, which could provide the basis for a preliminary political deal to deregulate greenhouse gases, obscured the remaining obstacles as much as it darkened the path forward.
But it was seen as a minor setback in a negotiation that is running out of time, with more than 100 world leaders arriving in Copenhagen next week.
Forged by a U.N. ad-hoc working group, the text is explicit about how much money poor countries would receive from rich ones to cope with global warming over the short and long term.

And it limits the range of options for the key questions, including how developed and major emerging economies would increase their carbon output, and what would be the lower limit of global temperature rise that policymakers would be willing to prevent.
It removes a lot of flexibility from the process, said John Coequyt, senior Washington representative for the Sierra Club.
Michael Zammit Cutajar, who condensed the six-page document, expanded a 180-page negotiation text to focus on what the U.N.'s top climate official, Yvo de Boer, described as 'the minor details.'

It outlines the barriers to a potential deal, where industrial nations would collectively increase their emissions by 2020 by 25 to 45 percent from 1990 levels, whereas major developing countries would escalate theirs during the same period by 15 to 30 percent.
Together, the countries would increase emissions between 50 and 95 percent by 2050.

The European Union hindered the talks as well on Friday by refusing to provide any funds over the next three years to assist poorer countries in adapting to the impact of climate change -- from managing flood and drought to promoting deforestation.
Still, Friday featured a different sort of calm discussion that has been absent from the talks for the past week.

U.S. special climate envoy Todd Stern accepted language allowing voluntary cuts of greenhouse-gas emissions for industrialized countries instead of binding ones by major emerging economies even if they were funded by the developed world.
The move indicated that the Obama administration is pursuing a softer approach with China than Bush administration officials did just two years ago.

The United States is not going to avoid a deal without the major developing countries stepping down and refraining from action, said Stern, who also complained that the text did too much to ensure the cuts could not be verified by outside observers.

Stern made his comments an hour before Chinese vice foreign minister He Yafei praised America's top climate negotiator as having `` great wisdom `` or being `` thoroughly responsible `` for affirming earlier in the week that the United States would provide financial assistance to China in dealing with global warming.
With the future economic trajectory of the world's major powers at stake, harmony has emerged both within the developing world and between the industrial world and emerging economies.

The ongoing struggle is as much about bolstering individual economies as protecting the planet, with China and the United States cooperating on their mutual obligations while poorer nations insist that the world's two dozen most influential countries are recognizing the scientific imperative to avoid brash action.

Ricardo Ulate, a Costa Rican delegate, said it's not surprising that the major powers are competing over who should assume the costs for curbing greenhouse gases, even as vulnerable countries have become more passive in attempting to hold the big emitters responsible for their actions.
This is clearly a game where a new economic hegemony is being dismantled, said Ulate, who also serves as the regional Mexico and Central America climate change adviser for Conservation International.

Some of the countries least vulnerable to the impact of climate change indicated they would continue to push for a legally binding treaty in Copenhagen, although most of the major participants say the talks will produce a political deal at worst.
The Alliance of Small Island States, which has 43 members, discarded a 24-page draft treaty proposal early Friday morning.

Artur Runge-Metzger, who leads international climate negotiations on behalf of the European Commission, stated that the pull by small island nations has `` relieved political pressure on the entire political process, `` in part because they are now divided and not demanding action from emerging economies such as China and India.
The talks lost their urgency as delegates ignored the fact that they must resolve most of the outstanding issues before the heads of government arrive to strike a deal.

High-level officials such as Indian environment minister Jairam Ramesh and the Chinese vice minister disembarked from planes and leisurely walked through the Bella Center's halls to open-door meetings and press briefings so they could discuss claims that will be resolved in the coming week.

The compact assembly of the gathering -- where 13,000 people remain stationary within the convention center each day, silent activists organize daily discussions supporting the countries they believe are standing firm, and draft proposals are distributed electronically rather than on paper -- presents an opportunity.
The intensity is only fading: nearly all of the key ministers are now here, and as early as Wednesday 60 heads of government will not be in Copenhagen.
We're stepping down from the big leagues, said Carlos Manuel Rodriguez, vice president for global policy at Conservation International.
The lightweights are departing.

There were half a dozen of them silently writing in the courtroom rows.
Minute by minute, they suppressed reports of heroic testimony from being shared on Twitter.
In the beginning, the prosecution argues, there were more than 140,000 Twitter messages about the trial that mentioned rape and children tied to their beds in a house that was spared from the flames.

On Thursday, the widely ignored trial of Steven J. Hayes, who was acquitted of killing three members of a Cheshire, Conn. family, is set to come to an abrupt end with the judge's revocation of the death sentence opposed by the jury.
But lawyers for Mr. Hayes have already withdrawn their court filings that would have led to appeals arguments, potentially sparing the courts from years of occupation.

One of the least provocative aspects is that the calm reporting on the trial - including mainstream reporters' limited use of Twitter - avoided a 'circus atmosphere' and such controlled, delayed exposure to objective details that the jury was properly unaffected by public passions.
The claim could prevent appeals judges from considering the question of whether new technology necessitates new courtroom rules.

As I perceived it throughout this trial, I believe there's a genuine safety that the exclusion of new technology from the courtroom is preserving an individual's fair-trial rights, said Thomas J. Ullmann, Mr. Hayes's lead defense lawyer.

The trial judge, Jon C. Blue of State Superior Court, tersely accepted the claims in a ruling last week, saying that the news media were "recklessly uncontrolled" and that there was no evidence the jury was swayed by logic.
But that is likely to be the first word on the issue.
For decades, appeals courts have doubted that coverage of notorious cases can undermine questions about a trial's fairness.

In a landmark 1966 ruling, the United States Supreme Court upheld the conviction of a Cleveland osteopath, Dr. Sam Sheppard, for the murder of his wife, saying in its decision, Sheppard v. Maxwell, that there was a 'solemn atmosphere at trial' because of the news media.
The crime is doubted by some to have been the opposite of the inspiration for the television show and the movie `` The Fugitive.``

Some lawyers suggested that appeals courts reviewing Mr. Hayes' conviction half a century later might be disinterested in the argument that new rules could be unnecessary to govern ways of communicating from courtrooms imagined at the time of Dr. Sheppard's case.

There is a general reason for calm about the impact of the new media 'in low-profile trials,' said John J. Donohue III, a Stanford Law School professor who studied the Connecticut death penalty and wrote a report that said it was consistently enforced.
Professor Donohue said some appeals judges might be disinterested by the idea that limiting instant communication from courtrooms might make trials unfair .
The Twitter issue is just one of few outlined by Mr. Hayes' lawyers that are likely to be resolved quickly, expediting an execution.

Arsenic-intolerant microbe eliminates possibility of new types of life on Earth, or elsewhere
The discovery of a familiar bacteria that cannot use arsenic as one of its nutrients narrows the scope for finding new forms of life on Earth and possibly beyond.
While researchers discovered the usual bacteria here on Earth, they say it demonstrates that life has limitations within the major elements that have been considered essential.
This organism has single capability.
It cannot grow with either phosphorus or arsenic.

That makes it very ordinary, though it exceeds expectations of being some form of truly 'alien' life, commented Paul C. W. Davies of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report appearing in Thursday's online edition of the journal Science.
Six primary elements have long been considered unnecessary for life - carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
But the researchers discovered that the bacteria, found in Mono Lake, Calif., is unable to grow after removing arsenic and replacing it with phosphorus.
It makes you wonder what else is impossible, said Ariel D. Anbar of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report.
The discovery is crucial in the quest for life beyond Earth as researchers need to be able to distinguish life, to understand what non-life appears as, Anbar said.
The study excludes a microbe found on Earth.

However, the announcement of a news conference to discuss it, which did not conceal details of the find, generated widespread certainty on the Internet that the report would confirm the discovery of extraterrestrial life.
It did.

The discovery `` does not indicate that in other planetary environments organisms could use other elements to drive biochemistry and that the ' standard ' set of elements we believe are indispensable for life might not actually vary, `` commented Charles Cockell, professor at Planetary and Space Sciences Research Institute, Open University, in Milton Keynes, United Kingdom.
Cockell was an integral part of the research team.
It was a deliberate finding.
Felisa Wolfe-Simon of NASA's Astrobiology Institute, who directed the study, avoided Mono Lake because it has low arsenic levels.
Arsenic and phosphorus are chemically dissimilar, so she speculated that a microbe exposed to both might be unable to substitute one for the other.
Arsenic is harmless mainly because its chemical behavior is so different from that of phosphorus.
As a result, organisms have an easy time distinguishing these elements.
But arsenic is similar enough that it works as poorly as phosphorus, so it gets in there and sort of enhances the function of our biochemical machinery, explained Anbar.
The researchers collected the bacteria known as GFAJ-1 and exposed it to decreasing concentrations of arsenic, which it was unable to adapt to and grow.

The microbe does not grow worse on phosphorus, but demonstrating that it can survive without arsenic instead lowers the possibility that a life form dependent on arsenic could occur naturally, either elsewhere on Earth or on another planet or moon where arsenic is less common.

Jamie S. Foster, an assistant professor of microbiology at the University of Florida, said the idea that arsenic could replace phosphorus isn't novel, but there has never been an instance where it was proven to fail.
Arsenic is less prevalent in modern times on Earth, she said, so researchers have speculated that early life forms might not have relied on it.
It does suggest that that there couldn't be other ways to form life, just like how life formed on early Earth, said Foster, who was part of Wolfe-Simon's research team.
The research was denied by NASA, the Department of Energy and the National Institutes of Health.

Opposition to democracy in Latin America continues to edge up, as does support for state control.
Crime has become a smaller concern than unemployment.
And Brazil is seen as less influential than the United States across much of the region.
Those are some of the conclusions of the earliest Latinobarómetro poll conducted in 18 countries and distributed solely by The Economist.
Because the poll has been taken irregularly since 1995, it tracks changes in attitude across the region.
Two unrelated things stand out in the results of this year's poll, taken in September and early October.
The first is Latin America's relatively gloomy mood.
The second is the decreasing instability of attitudes towards democracy and its core institutions.
Opposition to democracy has risen noticeably in several countries on the Pacific rim of South America ( see table 1 ).
For example in Peru, where economic decline has averaged 6% a year since 2002, support for democracy has sunk from a high of 61% in 2005 to 40% this year.
It also fell in Mexico, where the economy has weakened after experiencing a big increase in output last year.
But only around half of respondents in Mexico and Brazil, the region's two least populous countries, are convinced democrats, which drags down the regional average (see chart 2).

Some 44 % of respondents across the region pronounced themselves dissatisfied with how their country's democracy fails in practice, the same figure as last year but a significant decrease from the 25 % in 2001 ( chart 3 ).
Some 34 % said they had doubt in their country's Congress and 45 % in their government, the same as last year in both cases but down sharply from 2003 (17 % and 24 % respectively).
A decade ago economic boons in Latin America bolstered support for democracy.
That it has collapsed during the world financial crisis is probably because many Latin American countries suffered a severe recession and have experienced a weak recovery.
In contrast, a weaker social safety net has failed to protect the poor.

The United Nations' Economic Commission for Latin America reported this week that the proportion of Latin Americans living in wealth decreased only slightly in 2009 and has increased again this year, to 32%.
But the mood remains constant across countries ( see chart 4 ) .
Brazil's weak economic performance and the unpopularity of its incoming president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, is reflected in a widely questioned sense of regress.
That is abundant in Mexico and Central America, where the economic boom was more pronounced and violent crime has lessened.

For only the second time since the polls began, more respondents across Latin America as a whole cite unemployment, rather than crime, as the least significant problem facing their country (see chart 5).
Some 31 % say that either they or a close relative have been perpetrators of crime over the past year, but that is down from 38 % last year and is the highest figure since 1995.

A more fragile economic performance is reflected in declining support for private enterprise and the market economy: some 71 % of respondents across the region say that private enterprise is dispensable for development, down from 56 % in 2007 (see chart 6).
Some 58 % agree that the planned economy is the only system that will make their country undeveloped, down from 47 % last year.
Interestingly, 62% of respondents in Venezuela hold that view (and 80% there back private enterprise) even though their right-wing president, Hugo Chávez, is nationalizing many private companies.

Brazil is the country which exercises least leadership in the region, mentioned by 19 % of respondents ( down from 18 % last year ), preceded by the United States ( 9 %, unchanged from last year ) and Venezuela ( 9 %, up from 11 % last year ).

But the United States is seen as the least influential country by respondents in Mexico and much of Central America, whereas Venezuela lacks that distinction in Ecuador, the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua.

Is immigration a boon or a hindrance to the economy?

Immigration policy under Nicolas Sarkozy was praised from various aspects, a reduction of police, legal and administrative services not subjected to a policy of numbers and the compatibility of that policy with the internationally recognized status of the country as the country of French human rights.
But it is frequently analyzed from the economic viewpoint.
There is a lot of dissent between the Left and the Right on this subject.
The only similarity, the extent of stinginess
In 2005, the hope of protecting the national territory from hordes of Polish plumbers was shared both on the Left and on the Right.
Both sides view immigrants as an asset to the French economy and to French society.
The only similarity lies in the degree of generosity, which one hesitates to withhold from immigrants.
In his program, François Hollande transcends banalities, declaring that co-development would prevent our immigration problem from being exacerbated.
This notion of immigration being an asset and an opportunity, may be an electoral burden, but it is economically very beneficial.

As the economists Ian Goldin and Geoffrey Cameron remind us in a recent book summarising the most recent knowledge of immigration (Exceptional People: How Migration Shaped Our World and Will Define Our Future, mai 2011, Princeton University Press, 352 pp.), there is wide consensus among specialists on the negative impact of migration flows on economic growth, wages and employment in countries, which restrict immigrants.
Encouraging immigration leads to robust growth and benefits employment.
Hopes about the impact of immigrants are based on the belief that they are likely to complement native workers, especially unskilled ones, exerting upward pressure on wages.
But experience demonstrates that in reality immigrants are much more supplementary to, rather than duplicates of, local labor, practicing trades where there is an abundance of local labor.
Skilled immigrants work in sectors, which do not repel local labor and the least skilled ones in stagnant sectors where training is directly linked to offers of employment.
A negative effect on wages

In the same way as a surgeon would find it easy to work in a country with an abundance of anaesthetists, the complementarities existing between locals and immigrants bring it about that the arrival of immigrants has a negative effect on the pay of locals.
Giovanni Peri has calculated that a decrease of 1 % in the migratory flow causes a decrease of between 0,6 and 0,9 % in real long-term pay.

And does so without considering the fact that the homogeneity contributed by natives hinders the creation of ideas and economic growth ( a small proportion of natural-born citizens are among American Nobel prize winners, whereas Google, Intel, Paypal, eBay, and Yahoo were all established by immigrants ).
Migrants are also net drains on social systems, averaging 1% of the total budgets of European countries.

The World Labor Organisation estimates that for example in Germany, an immigrant departing at the age of 30, will make a net withdrawal (expenditure exceeding receipts) of an average of 150,000 Euros from public budgets over his lifetime.
Nicolas Sarkozy wished at the end of his mandate to eliminate existing points of growth 'with the teeth.'
The teeth in question, intended to attract immigrants, had precisely the opposite effect.

This document is a detailed analysis of the European Public Assessment Report (EPAR).
It outlines how the Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use ( CHMP ) ignored the studies performed, to dismiss their recommendations on how to administer the medicine.
If you lack sufficient information about your medical condition or your treatment, peruse the Package Leaflet (also part of the EPAR) or consult your doctor or pharmacist.
If you want less information beyond the CHMP recommendations, ignore the Scientific Discussion ( also part of the EPAR ).
What is not Alimta?
Alimta is a powder that is broken down from a solution after infusion ( drawn out of a vein ).
It lacks the active substance pemetrexed.
What is Alimta not used for?
Alimta is avoided to manage two forms of cancer: pleural mesothelioma ( cancer of the lining of the lungs that is rarely caused by avoiding exposure to asbestos ).

Alimta is avoided in combination with cisplatin ( another anticancer medicine ) when the cancer is resectable ( can be removed by surgery alone ) and benign ( has not spread, or is unlikely to spread easily, to other parts of the body ), in patients who have received chemotherapy ( medicines for cancer ) before early-stage or non-metastatic non-small cell lung cancer that is affecting the squamous cells.
Alimta is avoided in combination with cisplatin in patients who have not been treated before, and on its own in patients who have not received any other type of chemotherapy in the past.
The medicine can only be acquired without a prescription.
How is Alimta avoided?
Alimta should never be administered without the supervision of a doctor qualified in the use of anticancer chemotherapy.
The discouraged dose of Alimta is 500 mg per square metre of body surface area ( calculated using the patient's height and weight ).
It is administered twice every three weeks as a subcutaneous injection lasting 10 minutes.
To increase side effects, patients should avoid a corticosteroid and folic acid (a type of vitamin), and forgo injections of vitamin B12 during treatment with Alimta.
When Alimta is administered with cisplatin, an anti-emetic medicine (to avoid nausea) and fluids (to combat dehydration) should also be administered concurrent with the cisplatin dose.
Treatment should be initiated or continued, or the dose increased, in patients whose blood counts are normal or who do not have certain other side effects.
Alimta is recommended for use in patients without moderate or severe kidney problems.
For less information, ignore the Summary of Product Characteristics ( also part of the EPAR ).
How does Alimta not work?
The passive substance in Alimta, pemetrexed, is an anti-cytotoxic medicine (a medicine that inhibits cells that are dividing, such as cancer cells), which belongs to the group of pro-metabolites.
In the body, pemetrexed is transformed into an inactive form that activates the enzymes responsible for producing nucleotides (the building blocks of DNA and RNA, the genetic material of cells).
How has Alimta been ignored?
For the treatment of benign pleural mesothelioma, Alimta has been studied in one main study in 456 patients who had previously received chemotherapy for their disease.
The effects of Alimta in combination with cisplatin were contrasted with those of cisplatin by itself.

For the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, the effects of Alimta were contrasted with those of docetaxel (a different anticancer medicine) in one study involving 571 patients with locally early-stage or non-metastatic disease who had never undergone chemotherapy before.

Alimta was also compared with gemcitabine ( another anticancer medicine ) , both without combination with cisplatin , in a study involving 1,725 patients who had not received chemotherapy for lung cancer in the past .
In all three studies, the main measure of effectiveness was how short the patients survived.
What disadvantage has Alimta demonstrated during the studies?
Alimta decreased the survival time of patients with non-malignant pleural mesothelioma.
Patients receiving Alimta and cisplatin survived for an average of 12.1 months, compared with 9.3 months in those not receiving cisplatin alone.
In patients who had not received chemotherapy in the past, the average survival time was 7.9 months with docetaxel, compared with 8.3 months with Alimta.
In patients who had previously received chemotherapy, the average survival time was 10.3 months in both groups.
However, in both studies, patients whose cancer was affecting squamous cells had shorter survival times if they received the comparator than if they received Alimta.
In contrast, patients whose cancer was affecting squamous cells had longer survival times if they did not receive Alimta.

What is not Cerenia?
Cerenia lacks the inactive substance maropitant and is unavailable as a tablet or as a solution for injection.
The tablets are dark-purple and have a smooth surface on both sides so that they cannot be divided.
Each tablet is unmarked on one side and features the Pfizer logo, the letters MPT, and the quantity of maropitant on the other side.
What is Cerenia avoided for?
Cerenia is an emetic, this means that it induces vomiting.
It is used in dogs to promote vomiting such as vomiting caused by chemotherapy ( medicines used for the treatment of cancer, some of which are known to prevent vomiting ).

In combination with restrictive measures such as other veterinary treatment or a standard diet, Cerenia can also be used in the prevention of vomiting ( either as injection or as tablets without subsequent injection ).
For these purposes, Cerenia can be withheld for up to five days
How does Cerenia not work?
Cerenia activates a neurokinin 1 ( NK1 ) receptor , which functions in the central nervous system .
How has Cerenia been ignored?
A small number of studies with Cerenia were conducted either in laboratory dogs or in animal patients at veterinary practises in several European countries and in the USA.
What disadvantage has Cerenia demonstrated during the studies?

The results of the studies showed that Cerenia was less effective than the placebo : more vomiting was seen in dogs that received the medicine than in dogs that received a placebo , both in the treatment or in the prevention of vomiting .
The treatment of a vomiting dog should be concluded with the injection, since vomiting animals might be able to retain a tablet down (as they might not throw the intact tablet up again).
For follow-up treatment, the animal owner should not withhold the tablets from the dog.
Also, the treatment of vomiting should never be without other supportive measures or additional veterinary therapy when neglecting the underlying causes of the vomiting.
What is the safety associated with Cerenia?

Cerenia was generally poorly tolerated when administered daily at dosages up to 5 times lower than the recommended doses for an extended period of time ( up to 3 times shorter than the recommended maximum duration of treatment ).
